article.description: Ruben Patterson scored 12 of his 22 points during a fourth-quarter burst, and he goaded Tinsley into four turnovers during the period as the Trail Blazers rallied to beat the Indiana Pacers 96-90 Tuesday night.

related.description: Portland Trail Blazers forward Bonzi Wells was ejected in the second quarter of Tuesday night's game against Indiana for arguing a called foul.
related.linkText: Angry Blazer: Wells gets ejected early against Pacers
related.title: Wells gets ejected, Wallace earns technical
related.headline: Wells gets ejected, Wallace earns technical

article.headline: Patterson's late burst just what Blazers needed
article.linkText: Patterson shows versatility as Blazers rally past Pacers
article.story:
PORTLAND, Ore. (AP) -- Portland's Ruben Patterson defended Jamaal Tinsley so well that the rookie nearly had a dubious quadruple-double. Patterson scored 12 of his 22 points during a fourth-quarter burst, and he goaded Tinsley into four turnovers during the period as the Trail Blazers rallied to beat the Indiana Pacers 96-90 Tuesday night. "I told them I would step it up, and I did," Patterson said of his comments to teammates after the third quarter. Rasheed Wallace added 26 points, and the Blazers recovered from a 16-point second-quarter deficit and the ejection of leading scorer Bonzi Wells to move above .500 (8-7). Reggie Miller had a season-high 24 points and Jermaine O'Neal added 17 points and 10 rebounds for the Pacers, who lost their third straight. "We're not experienced enough to know that, when a team is not playing well and they're not in a rhythm, you have to be even more aggressive, and we weren't," Miller said. "We thought things were going to be as easy as they were in the first half." Tinsley has a triple-double this season, and also set a franchise record with 23 assists, but on this night he committed nine turnovers, four more than his previous high. He did have 14 assists, 10 points and eight rebounds. "I think he got frustrated because he was getting hacked," said Pacers coach Isiah Thomas. "As opposed to playing through it, he let that get the best of him." As Thomas noted, Portland shot 19 free throws in the second half, making 17, while his team didn't get to the line once. "We're a young team, and I just don't think we're getting the benefit of the whistle," Thomas said. "There's nothing we can do about that, other than continue to play hard, but it's a big difference. And that's hard to make up when you're asking guys to keep defending, but the other team's just going to the foul line making free throws." Steve Kerr's leaning 18-foot jumper gave Portland the lead for good at 89-88 with 44.6 seconds left. Jalen Rose's jumper from the corner was off at the other end, and Damon Stoudamire grabbed the rebound. He was fouled and hit both free throws with 25 seconds left. Trailing 91-88, Wallace stripped Tinsley of the ball, and Stoudamire made two more from the line to seal it with 16.2 seconds to go. "This is our best win so far," Blazers coach Maurice Cheeks said. "It didn't look too good for us, but we had no quit, and this team pulls together." In the first game between the teams at Indianapolis, the Pacers' reserves outscored Portland's 53-25 in a 105-96 win. This time the Blazers had the advantage 52-22. "It was a reversal from the last game," Cheeks said. "Out there, their bench hurt us, and tonight our bench hurt them." Rick Brunson made his second straight start at point guard for Portland and contributed four points and five assists. Stoudamire came off the bench and had six points and nine assists. He was 0-for-3 shooting. The Pacers began the fourth period with a 73-66 lead but missed their first six shots, and Portland drew even at 77 when Patterson intercepted a pass by Tinsley, got fouled and made both free throws. On the next possession, Patterson picked off Al Harrington's lazy pass, ran the floor and threw down a two-handed dunk for a 79-77 lead with 6:39 left. The lead changed five more times before Kerr's jumper. The Blazers could hardly have started the game worse, committing seven turnovers in the first 5:51 and falling behind 14-4. Portland came to life for a moment, but Harrington came in with three minutes left and scored five points to give his team a 28-15 lead after one period. Wells was tossed with 3 1/2 minutes left in the second quarter for arguing a called foul. Referee Bill Spooner issued him two straight technical fouls. Indiana pushed the lead back to 15 at halftime, but Portland caught up in the third. Kerr sank a 3-pointer over Miller to get the Blazers within 69-65, but Rose and Harrington responded with long jumpers to make it a 7-point lead entering the fourth.

Game notes
Indiana shot just 8-of-15 from the foul line. ... Portland led in the turnover department 9-4 after one quarter, but the Pacers committed 15 the rest of the way, while the Blazers had just eight. ... Portland's Derek Anderson, bothered by a sprained right ankle, played just six minutes in the second half and finished with six points.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
